appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

field_reports.summary: ZMB: Drought - 01-2024 - Drought Declaration in Zambia
field_reports.description:
The Zambian president has declared a drought, disaster and emergency in Zambia. The government has called for local and international support.

The Southern half of Zambia is experiencing a drought. The provinces affected include North-Western, Southern, Western, Central and Eastern. The country started experiencing the dry spells from 20th January when the rains were expected to be at a peak and crops to establish.

The drought currently experienced has affected a total of 8 provinces across the country with highest impacts in Southern ,Central, Eastern, North-western, Western, and Lusaka Provinces. 1 million households have been affected, and the situation has resulted in devastating impacts, with about 1 million hectors of maize field affected out of 2.2 million hectors planted in 2023/2024 season.  

Crops expecially maize, legumes, grounds nuts, millet, soghum and others are withering due to insufficient moisture content. Water points are drying up making it difficult for people to access safe and clean water dor domestic consumption. Pasture is drying up making is difficult for livestock. Price for food items and other basic commodities has continued to rise due to high demand as most community members have to depend on the markets. 

The most affected directly are small scale farmers who depend on rainfed cropping, livestock keepers and all community members who depend on natural water bodies and shallow wells for water. 

The situatuin has come at the time when the government shared the Intergated Food Insecurity Phase Classification (IPC) report indicating that in the period October 2023 and March 2024 an average of 2.04 million people are facing food insecurity.

results.summary:
The Southern half of Zambia is experiencing a prolonged dry spell. The provinces affected include Southern, Western, Central and Eastern. The country started experiencing the dry spells from 20th January when the rains were expected to be at a peak and crops to establish. 

Crops expecially maize, legumes, grounds nuts, millet, soghum and others are withering due to insufficient moisture content. Water points are drying up making it difficult for people to access safe and clean water dor domestic consumption. Pasture is drying up making is difficult for livestock. Price for food items and other basic commodities has continued to rise due to high demand as most community members have to depend on the markets. 

The most affected directly are small scale farmers who depend on rainfed cropping, livestock keepers and all community members who depend on natural water bodies and shallow wells for water. 

The situation has come at the time when the government shared the Intergated Food Insecurity Phase Classification (IPC) report indicating that in the period October 2023 and March 2024 an average of 2.04 million people are facing food insecurity.
results.name: ZMB: Drought - 01-2024 - Zambia Prolonged dry spells

field_reports.summary: ZMB: Other - 10-2023 - Anthrax Outbreak in Zambia- 335 cases and 4 deaths
field_reports.description:
A cumulative 335 cases and 4 deaths have been reported across the country in the following provinces:

Southern Province: Two hundred and sixty nine (269) cases and 2 deaths have been reported in the province. They are distributed as Sinazongwe with 242 cases including 2 deaths; Kazungula with 17 cases; Livingstone with 6 cases; Monze with 2 cases; and 1 case each in Choma and Kalomo.

Western Province: Nineteen (19) cases have been reported in the province distributed as 9 in Sesheke, 6 in Mongu , 3 in Nalolo and 1 in Sioma.

Eastern Province: Thirty (30) cases have been reported in Eastern Province. Lumezi district has recorded 28 cases with 1 death whereas Lundazi has recorded 2 cases.

Lusaka Province: The province has reported 13 cases in Lusaka District with 5 in Kanyama and 6 in Matero, 1 in chelstone and 1 in chilenje sub-districts.

Northwestern Province: One (1) case has been reported in Kasempa District. The patient is said to have travelled from Southern Province with a history of eating meat from a carcass with unknown cause of death.

Muchinga Province: Three (3) cases have just been reported in Mpika District of Muchinga province from Nabwalya Rural Health Center. Sadly we have lost a 12 year old boy among the 3 cases. Nabwalya is an area which borders Mambwe district in Eastern province. As we speak a multisectoral team from Health and Agriculture is on the way to the area.

The outbreak is spreading fast and affecting the neigboring towns of DRC, Malawi and Tanzania and hence the fear that the spread might go out side the country.

field_reports.description:
The Government did a press Briefing and indicated the following. 
A cumulative 335 cases and 4 deaths have been reported across the country in the following provinces:
Southern Province: Two hundred and sixty nine (269) cases and 2 deaths. Sinazongwe with 242 cases 2 deaths; Kazungula 17 cases; Livingstone 6 cases; Monze 2 cases; and 1 case each in Choma and Kalomo.
Western Province: Nineteen (19) cases distributed 9 in Sesheke, 6 in Mongu , 3 in Nalolo and 1 in Sioma.
Eastern Province: Thirty (30) cases. Lumezi 28 cases and 1 death, Lundazi 2 cases.

Lusaka Province: 13 cases - Lusaka District with 5

Northwestern Province: One (1) case - Kasempa District. 

Muchinga Province: (3) cases - Mpika 

Towns closer to Malawi, DRC, Namibia and Tanzania also are affected and the disease might spread in neibouring countries.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The cholera outbreak in Zambia has exhibited a concerning spread, with a progression from the initial cases in Lusaka Province to subsequent outbreaks in multiple regions. The situation has evolved since October 2023, with the current status as follows:

Outbreak Progression:

Lusaka Province: The outbreak originated in cholera-prone areas around October 2024.
Eastern Province: Cases were identified and linked to neighboring countries, specifically Malawi and Mozambique.
Northern, Central, Southern, Copperbelt, and N-Western Provinces: The outbreak has spread to these regions, indicating a widespread public health concern.
Geographical Spread:

Provinces Affected: Out of the nine provinces in Zambia, six have confirmed cholera outbreaks.
Districts Affected: A total of 33 districts have reported cholera outbreaks, emphasizing the extensive reach of the epidemic.
Cumulative Cases and Mortality:

Total Cases: The cumulative number of cholera cases stands at 6,272, reflecting the scale of the outbreak.
Deaths: Tragically, there have been 249 reported deaths, resulting in a Case Fatality Rate (CFR) of 4.0%.
Surveillance and Response:

Imported Cases: The Copperbelt and Muchinga Provinces have experienced imported cases from Lusaka. This highlights the interconnectedness of regions and the potential for the disease to spread across provincial borders.
Heightened Surveillance: Given the imported cases, there is an intensified focus on surveillance in Copperbelt and Muchinga Provinces. This proactive approach aims to detect and manage cases promptly, preventing further transmission.
field_reports.description:
The ongoing cholera outbreak, which initially emerged in peri-urban areas of Lusaka Province in October 2024, has significantly impacted public health across various regions in Zambia. The repercussions extend beyond mere statistics and underscore the broader health implications:

Geographical Spread and Regional Impact:

The progression of the outbreak from Lusaka to Eastern, Northern, Central, Southern, Copperbelt, and N-Western Provinces emphasizes the widespread health threat.
The cross-border linkages to Malawi and Mozambique highlight the interconnectedness of regions, posing challenges to containment efforts.
Cumulative Cases and Mortality:

The cumulative total of 6,272 confirmed cholera cases underscores the magnitude of the health crisis.
With 249 reported deaths, the Case Fatality Rate (CFR) of 4.0% reflects the severity of the outbreak and the challenges in providing timely medical intervention.
District-Level Impact:

The confirmation of cholera outbreaks in 33 districts intensifies the impact on local healthcare systems, placing a strain on resources and infrastructure.
Imported Cases and Surveillance Measures:

results.summary:
The ongoing cholera outbreak, which initially emerged in peri-urban areas of Lusaka Province in October 2023, has significantly impacted public health across various regions in Zambia. The repercussions extend beyond mere statistics and underscore the broader health implications.

Geographical Spread and Regional Impact: The progression of the outbreak from Lusaka to Eastern, Northern, Central, Southern, Copperbelt, and N-Western Provinces emphasizes the widespread health threat. The cross-border linkages to Malawi and Mozambique highlight the interconnectedness of regions, posing challenges to containment efforts. At the district-Level, the confirmation of cholera outbreaks in 39 districts intensifies the impact on local healthcare systems, placing a strain on resources and infrastructure. 

Cumulative Cases and Mortality: As of 11 January 2024, there were a cumulative total of 8,176 cholera cases. With 333 reported deaths, the Case Fatality Rate (CFR) of 4.0% reflects the severity of the outbreak and the challenges in providing timely medical intervention.
results.name: ZMB: October 2023 Cholera outbreak

Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

results.summary: On 22 January 2023, the Zambia Red Cross Society (ZRCS) received an alert on the Impact Based Forecasting (IBF) and Global Flood Awareness System (GloFAS). The system is able to detect riverine flooding and its connecting to water gauge stations managed by Water Resource Management Authority (WARMA) on water bodies across the country. The trigger statement indicates that the flood will be 20 years return flood, 7 days lead time, above 1000 HH and 100% threshold in the IBF and GloFAS. The early action activities will be implemented in 7 days. According to the system, there is a likelihood to experience floods in 10 districts across the country and potentially affecting a total of 100,264 people (16,712 Households). The IBF portal has pinpointed Kitwe district in the Copper Belt Province as likely to record the highest impact, estimated at 16,468 people, or 2,745 households. The anticipated floods are likely to occur on 28 January 2023. Photo of tiggered Impact Based Forecasting portal showing triggered stations and ZRCS Branches- 23rd January 2023, Credit: ZRCS and 510. EAP Activation Notification Zambia: Floods P a g e | 2 Public From the time the alert was received, the FBF Technical Working Group on Anticipatory Actions held a meeting to evaluate the situation and agreed to activate the EAP. The Government through DMMU and ZRCS Kitwe Branch is already in Kitwe district conducting some early warming information dissemination in high-risk communities through local radio stations. The government also broadcasted some mass SMS to the resident of Kitwe alerting them on the anticipated floods.
results.name: ZMB: Flood

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
Zambia has recorded 4 positive cases of Cholera. The first case was reported on the 11/04/2022 in Chelstone sub-District of Lusaka district in Lusaka province in Mtendere Compound. The case involves a 3 years old girls who presented with signs and symptoms suggestive of cholera, results showed vibrio Cholerae present in the stool. 

The other 2 cases are admitted at Matero level one clinic while the other is at Kalingalinga clinic and all in Lusaka district.
field_reports.notes_health: The NS work in close coordination and collaboration to facilitate the above selected activities
field_reports.notes_ns: The National Society is assisting Ministry of Health, donated 300 shippers (750mls *12 per case). Should the case of cholera rise, the National Society has prepositioned 20 ORP kits, 110 shipper of liquid chlorine, 3000 tablets of soap. 120 Volunteers in the affected district have also been alerted and Branch Transmission Interruption Team training for 20 volunteers will take place 19/04/2022. The volunteers to be trained have been selected from the affected locations and plans to scale up to other cholera prone districts are underway.
field_reports.description: On 11th April 2022 the country recorded one (1) positive case of Cholera and on 12th April 2022 the country recorded 3 more cases bringing the total to 4 cases. All the patients are admitted in health facilities are under treatment. Currently the NS is not affected in any way though members of staff are operating in fair.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

field_reports.summary: About 600 HH displaced and currently in 4 evacuation CENTRES
field_reports.description:
The country experiencd flash floods in a good number of districts including Namwala and Choma districts of Southern province. Zambia Red Cross Society conducted needs assessment and the following were the findings 

-There are 4 evacuation centres with one completely not accessible and close to 600 households registered in the evacuation centres  
-Food is an urgent need although the Government is providing mealie meal and beans (not adequate and not balanced)
-Shelter is a big challenge as tents provided by the Government not adequate for all displaced families and not durable and suitable for the water lodged places.
-No cooking places and families going out without food when it rains the whole day
-No latrines nor bathrooms in 4 camps, one centre is using school latrines sharing with pupils. Open defecation is being practiced and no lighting during the night  
-More Districts recording floods including Kalomo (160 households) and currently in Ndola, 113 families displaced and evacuated to schools where hygiene and food are priority challenges

results.summary:
Most parts of Zambia started receiving heavy rains on the 11th of January 2022. On the 16th of January 2022, Kalomo, Namwala, and Choma districts of the Southern Province started experiencing flash floods. According to the needs assessment report issued by the Zambian government through Disaster Management and Mitigation Unit (DMMU) (17th January 2022), Namwala district has recorded the highest number of households affected with 3,219. The report also indicated that 8,000 Ha of field crops have been submerged by water, as well as houses and sanitation facilities. In addition, livestock such as chickens and goats have also been swept away. Currently, 500 households have been displaced in Namwala and being accommodated in schools and the immediate needs include safe and clean water, hygiene and sanitation, food, Non-Food Items, shelter, and protection. 

A total of 4 communities in Namwala have been affected: Nakamboma, Mbeza, Chitongo and Mandondo. During the first days of the disaster, only 1 ward is accessible by road and the remaining 3 can only be accessed by air transport. DMMU is collaborating with Zambia Air Force (ZAF) to reach out to the affected population. This number is likely to rise due to the continuous rainfall that is being experienced in the district. According to the Zambia Meteorological Department flash flood monitor, which was issued on 19th January 2022, it is indicating that Namwala district will continue experiencing flash floods which is likely to worsen the situation.
results.name: Zambia/Namwala Flash Floods

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

field_reports.summary: Five people mission and over one hundred households displaced by Flood
field_reports.description:
On 26th December, 2020 Mumbwa district experienced heavy floods which lead to submerging and destruction of houses and sanitation facilities (Partial and complete damage). According to Zambia Red Cross Society that are on the ground conducts assessments, Over 120 families are displaced and 5 people are reported missing. As much as every one is affected as most services are affected such as communication, transport, access to markets, the critically affected people are as follows; children, aged, disabled and the chronically ill people. 

The most affected sectors include; Food, Waster and Sanitation and shelter.

results.name: Five people mission and over one hundred households displaced by Flood

field_reports.description:
According to Disaster Management and Mitigation Unit (DMMU), Rainstorm has destroyed houses affecting 500  families and the government just registered 342 families as the other ones are foreign national mainly from Malawi and don't have Zambian National Registration Cards for identity. The affected district is called Chipangali and is located in Eastern Province of Zambia. Currently the displaced families spending nights in the cold as the two nearby schools are destroyed as well. The affected sectors include shelter, food, WASH and livelihoods. Markets still exists and the nearest largest provincial capital is Chipata is 50 kilometers away from the affected district 
ZRCS is on the ground conducting as assessment, according to the reports, the most affected sectors are shelter, food and WASH
